Award.AwardTitle: UBM-Institutional: UCI Mathematical and Computational Biology for Undergraduates (MCBU)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Mathematical and Computational Biology for Undergraduates Program (MCBU) at the University of California, Irvine will provide a unique, collaborative type interdisciplinary training in knowledge and skills in systems biology for undergraduate students. The MCBU program consists of three key features:

1. A new mathematics major specialization in Mathematical Biology with
a innovative, flagship course sequence on Mathematical Modeling in Biology. This major
specialization directs math students to take courses in mathematics, biology, biochemistry,
biophysics and computer science which would best support work at the interface of mathematics,
computation and biology. The major capstone, cross-disciplinary research component will
prepare this group of students for graduate work or careers in high demand mathematical biology
fields.
2. A new minor in Applied Mathematics for Biology designed for students in various biology disciplines to supplement their biology training with relevant mathematics courses, including the course sequence on Mathematical Modeling in Biology.
3. Significant funded research opportunities for cross-disciplinary teams consisting of math and biology undergraduate students and faculty mentors. Every year there are topics from a range of biology fields available for student researchers, with each topic including significant laboratory, computing and mathematical analysis components. Research areas include: cell signaling, tumor growth modeling, viral dynamics, cell-to-cell feedback mechanisms, and others.

The Mathematical and Computational Biology for Undergraduates Program (MCBU) at the University of California, Irvine will provide undergraduate students training and research experience at the interface of biology, mathematics and computational science. Opportunities for the MCBU students include: foundational courses in biology, mathematics and computation, a year-long interdisciplinary course in Mathematical Modeling in Biology with emphasis on ties to current research, summer training boot camp in systems biology, year-long mentored interdisciplinary research led by a team of math and biology faculty, and attendance and participation at interdisciplinary mathematical biology and modeling conferences. The MCBU program includes a new major and minor in computational mathematical biology, which should provide this specialized interdisciplinary training to a broad audience of students, beyond just those funded for research under the UBM project. The MCBU program makes particular efforts to recruit a diverse group of students including underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Mathematical Computional Biology for Undergradutes (MCBU) program at the University of California, Irvine aimed to train students and provide research opportunities at the interface of mathematics, biology and computer science. Under the MCBU program:

  • 63 undergraduate science students participated in an 8-week summer undergraduate research program. Students were paired in mathematics and biology major teams and conducted research on problems involving use of mathematics and computation to advance our understanding of biological systems under the supervision of mathematics and biology faculty members. Students also participated in weekly professional skills workshops and gained skills in scientific writing, presentation, and research documentation.
  • We developed new degree undergraduate degree programs in Mathematical Biology. Under these new degree options, students took a combination of mathematics, biology and computer programming courses along with 3 newly designed Mathematical Modeling In Biology courses. These new degree options became available to students in 2012 and we have already had over 40 graduates with these degrees. 
  • We created original instructional content for a three-course sequence in Mathematical Modeling for Biolgy, including course notes and lecture videos. 

The MCBU program provided unique interdisciplinary training to undergraduate students and involved them in a variety of current research problems. Students used modeling to understand problems such as the effects of radiotherapy on solid tumor growth, the impact of fireworks fall-out on the bi-valve population in the Newport Back Bay, the relationship between HIV and the CTL response mechanism and the factors impacting pediatric bone development. 

In general, undergraduate research programs have been shown to impact student success, including retention and graduation rates. This impact was definitely seen in the MCBU program.100% of the MCBU undergraduate participants have completed or are on track to complete undergraduate degrees in the sciences. Many of our students have already gone on to graduate studies, often in mathematical biology programs.
